oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Entomopathogens Isolated from Invasive Ants and Tests of Their Pathogenicity
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Zarzuela, Maria Fernanda Miori
Leite, Luis Garrigós
Marcondes, José Eduardo
Carvalho Campos, Ana Eugênia
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: invasive ant
entomopathogen
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: <jats:p>Some ant species cause severe ecological and health impact in urban areas. Many attempts have been tested to control such species, although they do not always succeed. Biological control is an alternative to chemical control and has gained great prominence in research, and fungi and nematodes are among the successful organisms controlling insects. This study aimed to clarify some questions regarding the biological control of ants. Invasive ant species in Brazil had their nests evaluated for the presence of entomopathogens. Isolated entomopathogens were later applied in colonies of<jats:italic>Monomorium floricola</jats:italic>under laboratory conditions to evaluate their effectiveness and the behavior of the ant colonies after treatment. The entomopathogenic nematodes<jats:italic>Heterorhabditis</jats:italic>sp. and<jats:italic>Steinernema</jats:italic>sp. and the fungi<jats:italic>Beauveria bassiana</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>Metarhizium anisopliae</jats:italic>, and<jats:italic>Paecilomyces</jats:italic>sp. were isolated from the invasive ant nests.<jats:italic>M. floricola</jats:italic>colonies treated with<jats:italic>Steinernema</jats:italic>sp. and<jats:italic>Heterorhabditis</jats:italic>sp. showed a higher mortality of workers than control. The fungus<jats:italic>Beauveria bassiana</jats:italic>caused higher mortality of<jats:italic>M. floricola</jats:italic>workers. However, no colony reduction or elimination was observed in any treatment. The defensive behaviors of ants, such as grooming behavior and colony budding, must be considered when using fungi and nematodes for biological control of ants.</jats:p>
